The  Project  supports  the  country’s  efforts  to  reduce  poverty  and 
ease  social  tension.  The  Project  will  support  the  goals  of  the 
Tenth  Plan  (the  Government’s  poverty  reduction  strategy)   by   
(i)  supporting  the  delivery  of  market-oriented,  short-term  (MOST)

Nepal  faces  a  complex  development  setting  of  conflict  and 
political instability.  The  underlying  causes  of  the  conflict  include 
poverty and its manifestations in terms of regional, gender, ethnic,

rural communities and marginalized groups. The need is urgent to

lasting  solution  to  the  conflict.  In  its  poverty  reduction  strategy,

for  economic  growth,  social  sector  development,  social  inclusion

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

 
Nepal  faces  a  complex  development  setting  of  conflict  and  political  instability.  
2. 
The underlying causes of the conflict include poverty and its manifestations in terms of regional, 
gender,  ethnic,  and  caste-related  inequalities;  inadequate  governance;  and  failure  to  deliver 
adequate  and  essential  social  services  and  facilities  to  rural  communities  and  marginalized 
groups. Urgently needed are measures to address the chronic poverty and social exclusion, and 
achieve high economic growth to improve living conditions and achieve a lasting solution to the 
conflict.2  The  Tenth  Plan,3  which  is  also  the  Government’s  poverty  reduction  strategy, 
emphasizes economic growth, social sector development, social inclusion programs, and good 
governance. The plan articulates the seriousness and urgency of the conflict situation and the 
role  of  poverty.  Disadvantaged  groups  are  targeted  for  greater  participation  in  development, 
including  gaining  basic  education  and  skills  training  for  self-employment,  and  wage  and 
international  employment.  Greater  emphasis  is  also  to  be  given  to  encouraging  out-of-country 
employment.  
 
3. 
The Country Strategy and Program for Nepal  for 2005–2009 of the Asian Development 
Bank  (ADB)  (footnote  2)  supports  the  implementation  of  the  Tenth  Plan  and  focuses  on 
promoting  broad-based  and  inclusive  social  and  economic  development  to  contribute  to 
sustainable  poverty  reduction  and  help  reduce  social  tensions.  ADB’s  assistance  to  Nepal 
focuses on three areas that include  supporting  inclusive  social  and  human  development  and 
empowering  the  poor  and  disadvantaged  by  providing  basic  education  and  vocational  training 
needed to increase productivity and generate remunerative employment. 
 
A. 
 
4. 
Landlocked,  Nepal  is  the  12th  poorest  country  in  the  world.  In  2001  its gross domestic 
product  per  capita  was  $241,  the  lowest  in  the  South  Asia  region.  Its  population  stood  at   
23.2  million,  with  a  population  growth  rate  of  about  2.4%.  About  38%  live  in  poverty.  
The population is relatively young with children under 15 years constituting the dominant group 
(43%).  The  majority,  87%  of  the  population,  live  in  rural  areas.  The  country  has at  least 35 
ethnic  and  36  caste  groups  who  speak  different  languages  and  a  number  of  dialects as their 
mother tongue. Nepal’s economic performance is poor with low potential for improvement in the 
medium term. The economy is still predominantly based on agriculture, which comprises about 
40% of the gross domestic product. Manufacturing contributes 8% and services account for the 
rest.  Agriculture  production  fluctuates  from  year  to  year,  and  is  heavily  dependent  on  the 
monsoon.  The  Central  Region  is  the  most  developed,  followed  by  the  Eastern,  Western, 
Midwestern, and Far Western regions.4

move out of poverty. To take advantage of available jobs abroad, to be more competitive locally, 
and  to  engage  in  self-employment  activities,  greater  access  to  relevant  and  effective  skills 
training  programs  is  required.  However,  the  TEVT  sector,  and  particularly  vocational  training,  
is confronted with several issues in meeting this requirement.  
 
11. 
Inadequate Access to Training. The TEVT sector in Nepal performs poorly in terms of 
providing  access  to  training,  particularly  market-oriented  short-term  (MOST)  skills  training.  
Most  people,  particularly  the  poor  and  disadvantaged,  lack  access  to  skills  training  that 
enhances  earning  capacity.  About  200,000  people  seek  to  enter  the  labor  market  each  year. 
Yet, in the 1998  census, only 403,000 of a total working age population of 11 million indicated 
receiving  some  form  of  training.  No  more  than  50,000  a  year  currently  have  access  to  skills 
training.  TSLC  programs  run  by  CTEVT,  which  require  10  years  of  schooling,  cannot  be 
accessed  by  most,  particularly  the  poor,  women,  Dalits  (low  caste),  and  members  of 
disadvantaged  groups  because  of  their  lower  educational  achievement.  Short-term  training 
programs  linked  to  available  jobs  are  not  readily  available  and  are  mainly  offered  in a limited 
manner by CTEVT and private providers in large urban areas, which are difficult to access for 
those living  in distant areas.  Even  if  training  were  provided  free  of  charge,  attendance would 
mean that the poor must forgo daily wages. 
 
12. 
Poor Relevance of Training. The public TEVT system is largely supply-driven. Training 
programs  are  often  based  on  the  allocated  budgets  of  public  training  providers,  and  available 
staff and equipment. Training needs assessment (TNA) is weak and often absent; the available 
labor  market  information  system  is  unable  to  provide  up-to-date  labor  market  data  to  assist 
training  program  selection.  The  outcomes  of  both  rarely  guide  the  selection  of  skills  and 
contents, with the consequence that offered courses and their contents are regularly irrelevant 
to needs and demands. Linkages between educational institutions and industry are inadequate 
and have led to a lack of mutual cooperation. Thus, training institutions are often not fully aware

13. 
Training  programs  have  not  yet  significantly  refocused  on  the  emerging  needs  of  the 
labor  market.  While  the  major  potential  sources  of  employment and  income generation are in 
the informal/self-employment and foreign employment sectors,  training for these is insufficient. 
To improve the relevance of programs, training providers need to make a better determination 
of  trainees’  and  employers’  needs,  and  analyze  communities’  economic  opportunities.  
The  larger  public  training  providers  need  to  provide  more  MOST  skills  training  programs  for 
those  who  have  less  than  SLC .  The  participation  of  communities,  through  community-based

Low Quality of Training. In addition to being poorly identified, some training programs 
14. 
are  poorly  designed  and/or  poorly  delivered.  Curricula  are  not  sufficiently  regularly  revised  to 
reflect changing market demands. Training providers focus on delivering content, as specified in 
their curriculum, and not on achieving the performance expected  for employment, as specified 
in  skills  and  training  standards.  Trainers,  in  turn,  have  no  benchmarks  to  measure  their  own 
technical and instructional capability, and thus have no means of determining the gap between 
their  current  performance  and  their  desired  capability.  Performance  specifications,  or  skills 
standards, are needed as benchmarks for delivery and assessment. Many instructors, including 
those  employed  by  private  providers,  have  no  training  in  instructional  techniques  and  no 
extensive technical expertise; they are rarely upgraded.  Public training institutions have limited 
budgets,  not  allowing  them  to  train  staff.  Most  public  provider  sites  lack  tools,  equipment, 
materials, and supplies.  Monitoring  of  the  quality  of  training  programs  needs  to  be  improved. 
The present  CTEVT  accreditation system  needs to be  more  informative  and  transparent, and 
expanded to include emerging short-term programs, especially those aimed at foreign demand.  
 
Lack  of  Posttraining  Support.  Many  TEVT  providers  focus  solely  on  training  rather 
15. 
than  training  outcomes.  Most  do  not  provide  posttraining support, e.g., career placement and 
counseling.  Such  support  is  particularly  critical  in  training  for  self-employment  as  linkages 
should be provided to economic opportunities, e.g., jobs and microfinance programs.  Providers 
need to be trained to provide or link to such services. 
 
16. 
Need  for  TEVT  Coordination.  The  TEVT  sector  is  highly  fragmented.  Although  a 
national TEVT policy was approved in 1999 by the CTEVT  Assembly, this is not adhered to by 
all  stakeholders.  Skills  development  is  organized  by  government  ministries  (and  within 
ministries, by departments ), NGOs, aid projects, and, to some extent, local initiatives. The roles 
of the various stakeholders of the TEVT system have not been clearly defined and organized. 
Although CTEVT is the apex agency for TEVT policy coordination, the expansion of the number 
of  training  institutions  under  its  administration  has  resulted  in  it  focusing  on  training  delivery 
rather than on its role as an apex organization. It has been unable to provide an integrating role 
for  the  whole  system  of  TEVT  provision.  Most  TEVT-related  decisions  on  issues, including 
TEVT policy, allocation of resources, and system management, are made at the central level of 
CTEVT and within each of the respective line ministries with little consultation and participation 
of  key  stakeholders  such  as  the  private  sector  and  local  communities.  Most training providers 
work  to  their  own  benchmarks  and  curricula;  outcomes  are variable.  Consequently,  agencies 
have  no  common  purpose  or  comparable  outcomes.  Coordination  between  their  respective 
programs is limited, leading to duplication of activities, e.g., development of curricula and skills 
standards,  and,  therefore,  wastage  of  already  scarce  resources.  Information  relating  to  labor 
demand and the TEVT subsector, including training program information, trainees, and program 
efficiency  and  effectiveness,  are  scarce.  Moreover,  government  funding  for  training  to  each

Lessons Learned. ADB's past experiences with TEVT, including the last TEVT project 
in Nepal,9 highlight issues related to infrastructure utilization and increasing the level of training 
with existing resources. CTEVT has been unable to significantly expand the provision of training 
delivery  beyond  the  life  of  the  project  because  of  lack  of  resources.  The attention to service 
delivery  has  resulted  in  fewer  resources  available  to  enhance  its  standing  as  a  coordinating 
body. Experience with this project also emphasizes the need for CTEVT to refocus its direction 
to strengthen the TEVT sector as a whole, and thus perform a key strategic role, and reduce its 
attention  to  training  delivery,  which  can  be  undertaken  by  many  other  training  providers. 
Similarly,  the  Ministry  of  Industry,  Commerce,  and  Supplies  must  develop  the  capability  to 
facilitate training undertaken by private providers rather than necessarily delivering all training.  
 
18. 
In the international arena, the development of national frameworks such as qualification 
frameworks  and  skills standards,  when  adequately  contextualized  to  the  country,  have  served 
as  powerful  mechanisms  to  gain  consistency  of  approach  and  drive  a  demand-focused 
approach.10 Experiences of some development partners in Nepal have shown that training alone 
is  insufficient  to  gain  self-employment.  Too  much  training  occurs  without  any  employment 
outcomes. A holistic approach needs to be adopted that combines TNA,  which identifies skills 
needs as well as product markets; selection of trainees who are most likely to be entrepreneurs; 
where  appropriate,  delivery  of  quality  training  linked  to  employment  demand;  and  posttraining 
services.  Successful  outcomes  from  training  are  more  likely  to  occur  within  social  partnership 
arrangements.  A  strong  relationship  is needed  (i)  between  training  providers  and  the  funding 
authority,  which  leads  to  mutual  learning  and  ongoing  capacity  development  of  the  training 
provider; and (ii) between training providers, communities, and special interest groups.

Objectives 

 
A.  
 
21. 
The  goal  of  the  Project  is  to  promote  poverty  reduction  and  stability  by  increasing 
engagement in wage and  international  employment,  and  self-employment.  The  purpose  is to 
increase opportunities for MOST skills training by improving the relevance of and increasing the 
delivery  of  MOST  skills  training,  particularly  to  women,  Dalits,  and  the  disadvantaged.  
The  Project  aims  to  (i)  increase  access  to  MOST  skills  training,  particularly  by  women,  Dalits, 
and the disadvantaged; (ii) strengthen the capacity of key agencies to enhance their services, 
particularly  to  the  vocational  training  sector,  and  hence  improve  relevance  and  quality;  
(iii)  strengthen  training  providers  to  enhance  access  and  improve  the  relevance  and  quality  of 
training;  and  (iv)  develop  and  articulate  a  new  national  policy  to  achieve  greater  integration, 
relevance,  and  efficiency  in  the  TEVT  sector.  The  Project  will  serve  beneficiaries  from  all 
districts of the country.

increase  offered  wages.  The  involvement  of  various  line  ministries,  the  private  sector,  and 
manpower  agencies  in  determining  the  human  resource  needs  in  selected  sectors  and  in 
developing needed training programs will yield higher quality labor market information and more 
appropriate training  programs. The  coordination  efforts  among  these  various  stakeholders  will 
improve  the  matching  of  labor  supply  with  labor  demand,  especially  for  international  work.   
As some training will be oriented toward international work, remittances from employed trainees 
would contribute not only to national income, but also to  reducing pressures on the balance of 
payment.  Increased  incomes  from  employment  also  have  economywide  multiplier  effects  as 
these  are  spent  on  consumption  goods,  house  construction,  and  education,  among  others. 
Through  the  Project,  about  80,000  trainees,  including  women,  Dalits,  and  disadvantaged 
groups, will receive market-oriented and community-based skills training. Under the assumption 
that 60% will find  international or local employment, or engage in self-employment, the project 
investment  would  be  economically  justified  with  an  economic  internal  rate  of  return  of  28% 
(Appendix 10).

quality standards. Training providers will have greater access to materials developed at CTEVT

Project Assumptions and Risks 

 
B. 
 
66. 
Security Situation. The conflict situation and armed insurgency in the country represent 
major  risks  to  achieving  the  Project’s  development  goals.  The  Project’s  ability  to  identify  and 
deliver  training  in  communities  could  be  hindered  by  disruptions  caused  by  the  insurgency 
situation.  The  project  design  incorporates  lessons  learned  from  implementation  in  Nepal’s 
conflict  areas  (Appendix  11).  The  Project  emphasizes  local  participation  in  TNAs,  in  the 
organization  of  training  activities,  and  the  use  of  NGOs  or  CBOs  in  the  communities. Women, 
Dalits, and disadvantaged groups are targeted to comprise at least 60% of training beneficiaries 
in  communities.  District officials will be  given training in liaising with communities to increase 
their  responsiveness  to  communities’  needs.  Implementation  will  also  be  phased;  lessons 
learned  during  implementation of  skills  training  activities  in  the  first  year  will  contribute  to  fine-
tuning implementation arrangements, procedures, and criteria to better achieve project goals.  
 
67. 
Coordination.  The  Project  supports  the  development,  articulation,  and  initiation  of 
implementation  of  a  new  TEVT  policy.  The  establishment  of  a  new  national  TEVT  policy  to 
underpin  coordination and  quality  improvements  across  the  whole  subsector  depends on the 
commitment  of  government  providers  of  skills  development  training.  There  is  the  risk  that  line 
ministries’  commitment  to  a  coordinated  approach  to  skills  training  would  waiver.  Under  the 
Project, through their representation in the  Core Working Group,  PCC, and PoSC, and regular 
meetings of these groups, cooperation and coordination of activities through the Project will be 
encouraged. The Project supports a wide stakeholder consultation in the articulation of the new 
TEVT  policy. CTEVT’s capacity  to more effectively  undertake  policy  development  and  provide 
coordination and facilitation in the  subsector will be strengthened through the Project.  CTEVT’s 
coordination and accreditation role, and administration of training delivery may present a conflict 
of interest. However, CTEVT is presently moving toward a greater facilitation and coordination 
role.  Its  draft  5-year  plan  proposes  granting  autonomy  to  selected  CTEVT  training  institutions. 
The new TEVT policy will also directly address this issue.  
 
68. 
Participation of Private Training Providers. The Project aims to improve the quality of 
short-term training not only among public training providers, but also among private providers, 
by providing training to trainers, education managers, and senior staff. To boost the attendance 
of participants from private providers, the Project will publicize the training among the providers. 
In addition, the training will be implemented across the country, bringing it closer to prospective 
participants.  Quality  benchmarks  established  through  the  framework  may  drive  up  costs  of 
training  delivery  such  that  training  providers  may  opt  not  to  seek  accreditation  and  quality 
remains  low.  The  representation  of  multiple  stakeholders  on  the  various  committees  and 
working groups of the Project is one measure that will mitigate this risk, as will broad community 
and industry consultation in the development of the TEVT standards. Capacity-building activities 
will aid providers in meeting standards. In addition, project monitoring data will help identify the 
benefits of compliance and be disseminated to providers and trainees alike. 
 
69. 
Posttraining Services. The success of the  Project in meeting its goal depends on the 
increased  ability  of  training  recipients  to  enter  employment  or  self-employment,  or  generate 
income  as  a  result  of skills  training.  Posttraining  services,  however,  such as microfinance and 
product marketers, may  not  be  available.  To  minimize  this,  TNAs  will  take  into  consideration 
local  economic  opportunities.  The  Project  will also  build the  capacity  of  training  providers to 
identify  posttraining  support  services, including linking with  employers, marketers,  NGOs, and 
other CBOs.

SECTOR ANALYSIS 

 
1.  
The technical education and vocational training (TEVT) sector can be broadly described 
as training for specific occupational areas below the bachelor degree level. In Nepal,  a further 
distinction  is made  between  technical  education  and  vocational  training.  Technical education 
consists  of  training  for  the  nationally  recognized  qualifications  of  diploma  and  technical  school 
leaving certificate (TSLC). Technical education programs are between 2 and 3 years long, are 
strongly  linked  to  general  education  qualifications,  and  constitute  an  alternative  pathway  to 
university.  Vocational  training  programs  are  generally  less  than  6  months  in  duration  and  give 
trainees skills to earn an income. The TEVT subsector comprises both government and private 
training providers. Some are entirely focused on vocational training or technical education, while 
others offer both. The overall capacity is small at about 50,000 training places per year. Limited 
opportunities  for  places  in  government  institutions  have  led  to  the  expansion  of  private 
institutions, including those operated by nongovernment organizations.  
 
2.  
TEVT  is  largely  fragmented  in  Nepal.  No  national  policy  has  been  adopted  by  the 
subsector  as  a  whole.  Different  providers  follow  their  own  curricula  and  even  their  own  skills 
standards.  Nonetheless,  an  apex  body,  the  Council  for  Technical  Education  and  Vocational 
Training (CTEVT), exists. Primarily, however, the role of CTEVT has been to monitor the quality 
of private training providers especially  for TSLC programs. CTEVT has been unable to provide 
an integrating role over the whole system of TEVT provision.  
 
3.  
Council  for  Technical  Education  and  Vocational  Training.  CTEVT  was  created  in 
1989  through  the  Technical  Education  and  Vocational  Training  Act,  1989  (amended  in  1993). 
CTEVT  is  both  a  national  coordinating  body  for  TEVT  as  well  as  the major provider of TEVT. 
The  expansion  in  the  number  of  training  institutions  under  its  administration,  however,  
has  resulted  in  it  focusing  on  training  delivery  rather  than  on  its  role  as  an  apex  organization.   
A  refocus  to  a  facilitating  role  for  the  TEVT  subsector  has  recently  emerged  consistent  with 
directions  generally  provided  in  the  Tenth  Plan.  CTEVT  has  adopted  a  5-year strategic plan 
(2003–2008) that attempts to shift its focus from delivery of training, to guiding, facilitating, and 
regulating training.

vocational training and community development institutions, and technical schools.  In addition,

13.  
Issues in TEVT. The TEVT subsector in Nepal is highly fragmented. Although a national 
TEVT  policy  was  approved  in  1999  by  the  CTEVT  Assembly,  this  is  not  adhered  to  by  all 
stakeholders. Policy guidelines are available but not adequately implemented. The public sector 
is  characterized  by  weak  institutional  leadership.  CTEVT  is  too  burdened  with  implementation 
tasks.  The  roles  of  the  various  stakeholders  of  the  TEVT  system  are  not  clearly  defined  and 
organized.  Skills  development  is  organized  by  government  ministries  (and  within  ministries,   
by  departments),  nongovernment  organizations,  aid  projects,  and  to  some  extent,  by  local 
initiatives.  Coordination  between  these  various  actors  and  their  respective  activities  is lacking, 
leading  to  duplication  of  activities,  e.g.,  development  of  curricula  and  skills  standards,  and, 
therefore,  wastage  of  already  scarce  resources.  Most  training  providers  work  to  their  own 
benchmarks  and  curricula;  outcomes  are  variable.  Consequently,  the  agencies  have  no 
common  purpose  or  comparable  outcomes .  Most  TEVT-related  decisions  are  made  at  the 
central  level  within  each  of  the  respective  line  ministries  with  little  consultation  with  key 
stakeholders, such as the private sector and local communities. Moreover, government funding 
for training to each public agency is based on the needs of the given department rather than the 
priorities  within  the  training  market.  Incentives  and  rewards  for  well-performing  institutions are 
lacking, as are sanctions for nonperforming institutions. 
 
Training is of  poor relevance. The public TEVT system is largely supply-driven; training

available staff and equipment. Training needs assessment is weak and often absent; the labor

to  assist  training  program  selection.  The  outcomes  of  both  rarely  guide  the  selection  of  skills 
and content, with the consequence that offered courses and their content are regularly irrelevant

15.   National standards to measure skills levels are largely absent. Overall training efforts are 
not leading to a significant proportion of trainees gaining employment or self-employment, and 
thus not contributing much to poverty  reduction. Employment rates of trainees from CTEVT and 
private  training  institutes  range  from  30%  to  80%,2  which  is  partly  attributed  to outcomes of 
courses  not  being  the  attainment  of  skills  standards,  i.e.,  performance  defined  by  industry. 
Instead,  the  outcomes  are  the  skills  and  content  knowledge  of  the  curriculum,  the  quality  and 
relevance of which are questionable. Monitoring and evaluation mechanisms are inadequate or, 
in  some  cases,  absent.  Measurement  of  stakeholders’  performances,  accountability,  and 
transparency  in  budget  management  is  insufficient.  Monitoring  of  the  quality  of  training 
programs needs to be improved. The growing number of private training providers, a proportion

In  addition  to  being  poorly  identified,  training  programs  may  also  be  poorly  designed 
and/or poorly delivered.  The  development  of  curricula is too centralized, and curricula are not 
sufficiently  frequently  revised  to  reflect  changing  market  demands.  In  some  public  training

including  those  in  private  colleges,  do  not  possess  training  in  instructional  techniques  nor  do 
they have extensive technical expertise. Trainers and instructors’ skills and capacities are rarely 
upgraded.  Currently,  no  standards  exist  for  either  instructional  or  technical  expertise.  Many 
training instructors, public and private, have not had any instructional training or need to have a 
refresher  program  in  training  instruction.  Budgets  of  public  training  institutions  are  limited  and 
are thus not able to send their staff for training in vocational education pedagogy. Most public 
providers’ sites suffer from lack of maintenance, tools, equipment, materials, and/or supplies.   
 
17.    Many TEVT providers focus solely on training rather than the outcomes of training. Many 
do  not  provide  posttraining  support,  e.g.,  career  counseling  and  job  placement.  Posttraining 
support is particularly critical in training for self-employment, as providing linkages to economic 
opportunities like small business development activities and microfinance is important.  
 
Training  programs  have  not  yet  significantly  refocused  on  the  emerging  needs  of the 
18.  
labor market  or  of  large  population  groups.  While  the  major  potential  sources of employment 
and  income  generation  are  in  the  informal/self-employment  and  international  employment 
sectors, insufficient training is provided for jobs that are in demand and skills that lead to self-
employment.  To  improve  the  relevance  of  programs,  training  providers  need  to  make  a  better 
determination  of  trainees’  and  employers’  needs,  and  analyze  communities’  economic 
opportunities.  The  larger  public  training  providers  need  to  provide more programs addressing 
the needs of those with less than a school leaving certificate.  
 
19.  
The  TEVT  subsector  in  Nepal  performs  poorly  in  terms  of  providing  access  to  skills 
training, specifically market-oriented short-term skills training (vocational training). Most people, 
particularly  the  poor  and  disadvantaged,  lack  access  to  skills  training  that  can  enhance  their 
earning  capacity.  Competition  for  training  is  strong,  meaning  that  those  with  significant 
participation  in  secondary  school  education  have  a  better  chance  in  gaining  access.  This  is 
particularly  the  case  with  TSLC  programs  run  by  CTEVT  where  the  entry  requirement  is  10 
years  of  schooling.  This  particularly  limits  access  for  most  disadvantaged  groups  such  as 
women, the poor, and the disadvantaged communities, including Dalits (low caste), because of 
their lower educational achievement. The sector has no clear and effective strategy to reach the 
poor  and  the  disadvantaged  in  remote  villages.  The  tendency  for  training  to  be  provided  in 
training centers also makes access difficult for those living in distant areas.  Rural and isolated 
areas have little access to training when compared with urban centers. Government funding is 
insufficient to provide employment-related basic vocational or skills training to millions of people 
across  the  country.  Mobile  training  offered  by  DCSI  and  CSIDB  is  limited  by  the  budget. 
Information  being  provided  to  disadvantaged  groups,  including  women  about  the  potential 
benefits of skills training is insufficient. 
 
20. 
Toward a Coordinated TEVT Subsector.  Poverty reduction is a major goal for Nepal. 
Skills formation can play a major role in giving people employable skills to earn income. A fresh 
perspective  is  required  to  substantially  increase  the  number  of  people  who  acquire  skills  that 
lead  to  incomes.  The  creation  of  a  quality  market-oriented  TEVT  system  offers  such  a 
possibility. Such a system would have (i) acquired skills matching the performance needed for

A. 

GCE Strategy Goal 

1.  
The goal of the GCE strategy is to address the issue of social exclusion which prevents 
access and opportunity in Nepal for particular groups of people. An effective strategy for social 
inclusion requires both project and policy level intervention. The Project ensures better access 
to vocational training (VT) opportunities for employment and self-employment for target groups 
at  the  grassroots,  which  in  turn  provides  more  secure  access  to livelihood assets. Scaling up 
and  sustaining  improvements  beyond  the  life  of  the  Project  requires  representation  of  target 
groups  in  decision-making  at  the  national  policy  level.  It  is  expected  that  representation  in  the 
national  technical  education  and vocational training (TEVT) policy coordination committee and 
national and district steering committees for the Project will ensure more inclusive strategies for 
continued  access  to  vocational  training  resources  for  employment  and  self-employment and 
influence  thinking  among  all  stakeholders  for  training  interventions  in  support  of  greatersocial 
inclusion  and  equity,  and  improved  governance.  Representation  of  women,  Dalits  (low  caste) 
and the disadvantaged groups will hence be ensured. At district level, the composition of these 
groups will vary depending on the different caste-ethnic group compositions in districts.

Economic Analysis 

 
A.  
 
The Economy and  the  Labor Market.  Nepal’s  economic  performance  in  recent  years 
1. 
has been poor with low potential for improvement in the medium term. The  Nepalese economy 
is  largely  dependent  on  agriculture,  with  the  services  and  industry  sectors  growing  in 
importance.  Gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  in  fiscal  year  (FY)  2003  was  estimated  at  
$5.9 billion1 and the growth rate at 3.1%.2 The services and the agriculture sectors are the largest 
sectors  in  the  economy,  each  contributing  close  to  40%  of  GDP,  while  the  industry  sector 
contributed about  21%.  Remittances  from  workers  abroad  are  estimated  to  contribute  25%  of 
GDP.3 The services and industry sectors grew more than the agriculture sector in FY2003; the 
average  annual  growth  of  services  and  industry  sectors  were  2.7%  and  2.3%,  respectively, 
while the agriculture sector grew 2.1%. Agriculture employs the most workers, absorbing about 
75% of the labor force. In contrast, the services and industry sectors employ only about 23%.4 
The  total  unemployment  rate  is  estimated  at  17.4%,  which  is  largely  accounted  for  by 
underemployment;  the  unadjusted  unemployment rate is 5%.  Approximately  three  quarters of 
the underemployed are estimated to be in the agriculture sector. The Government estimates the 
labor  force  will increase  by  1.05  million  during  the  Tenth  Plan  period,  2002–2007,  or  about 
200,000 new workers each year. 
 
2. 
A  major  constraint  to  employment is the lack of  appropriate skills  needed  in  the  labor 
market.  A  reduction  in  underemployment  will  require  shifting  some  of  the  labor  force  from 
agriculture  to  the  other  sectors in  both  local  and  foreign  labor  markets  through  labor  market 
analyses  and  market-orientation  of  training  programs  in  technical  education  and  vocational 
training  (TEVT)  institutions.  The  current  provision  of  TEVT  has  had  little  success  in  delivering 
effective  training.  Ineffectiveness  stems  from  the  (i)  irrelevance  of  curricula,  (ii)  low  quality  of 
training, and (iii) lack of posttraining support. This has resulted in low external efficiency; the job 
placement rate of training completers is estimated at 50%. The TEVT sector  requires a change 
in its training delivery mechanisms to develop a more effective and efficient system. 
 
3. 
Demand  Analysis.  Demand  for  vocational  training  is  substantial.  About  200,000 
workers  enter  the  workforce  each  year.  As  the  completion  rate  of  secondary  education  is 
approximately 12%, approximately 88% of the new entrants to the workforce are likely to require 
training  for  basic  vocational  skills.  However,  only  50,000  places  are  available  for  vocational 
training each year, leaving a large demand gap. 
 
4. 
The  Tenth  Plan  provides  the  Government’s  strategy  for  employment  creation.  
The strategy indicates that demand for nonagricultural workers will increase, implying a need for 
nonagricultural  training  for  the  future  workforce.  In  2004,  75%  of  employment  will  be  in 
agriculture,  but the proportion will gradually  decline  to 70%  by  2007.  To  achieve  the  shift  of 
employment from agriculture to nonagriculture sectors, approximately 200,000 people, the same 
number  of  people  as  the  new  entrants  to  the  workforce,  will  be  recruited  in  nonagriculture 
sectors. Therefore, the economy will have sufficient demand for those with nonagricultural skills.

households headed by women constituted 13% of all households at the national level; this number is likely

primary and secondary school completion rates. However, large gender gaps remain in these indicators.

productivity through skill training to improve the 
likelihood of obtaining employment in formal and 
international work, and in self-employment.
